{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17439,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Resupinatus applicatus, commonly known as the \"Smoked Oysterling,\" is a type of mushroom rather than a typical plant, and it does not require the same care as a houseplant. However, if you're cultivating these mushrooms, you should ensure they are kept in a moist environment, as this promotes proper growth. Regular misting or covering with a humidity dome can maintain high humidity. Avoid overwatering as this can lead to mold or fungus other than your desired mushrooms."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Unlike traditional plants, Resupinatus applicatus does not need sunlight for growth. As a type of mushroom, they thrive in low-light conditions, ideally in indirect light or darkness with a controlled temperature. Direct sunlight can be detrimental as it dries out the substrate and the developing fungi. Ensuring a dark to dimly lit environment will support mushroom growth and mimic their natural habitat, typically found on decaying wood in forested areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Resupinatus applicatus, as they are mushrooms and not plants. Instead, focus on providing them with the right growing conditions such as adequate humidity, temperature, and a suitable substrate rich in organic matter. If you are cultivating them and see other fungi or mold growing, it is important to remove these contaminants promptly to prevent them from affecting the mushrooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Smoked Oysterling","description":"Resupinatus applicatus, commonly known as the smoked oysterling or the black jelly oyster, is a species of fungus in the family Tricholomataceae, and the type species of the genus Resupinatus. First described in 1786 as Agaricus applicatus by August Johann Georg Karl Batsch, it was transferred to Resupinatus by Samuel Frederick Gray in 1821.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Worldwide, particularly in temperate regions"],"other_name":["Smoked Oysterling"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Resupinatus applicatus"],"soil":[],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17140,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vernonia fasciculata, commonly known as ironweed, prefers consistently moist soil but can withstand short periods of dry conditions once established. Water the plant thoroughly during its growing season, especially in the absence of rain, but allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent waterlogging. In areas with regular rainfall, supplemental watering may only be necessary during extended dry spells. Ensure the plant is not sitting in waterlogged soil, as this can lead to root rot. Reduce watering in the dormant winter months when the plant's growth slows."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vernonia fasciculata thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and blooming. While it can tolerate partial shade, the plant may not bloom as profusely or grow as vigorously without sufficient light. Choose a planting location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day to ensure the best display of its striking purple flower clusters. In areas with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching and preserve moisture levels."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vernonia fasciculata primarily involves cutting back the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This helps promote a robust and tidy appearance, encouraging fuller growth and more vibrant blooms during the flowering season. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased stems throughout the growing season to maintain plant health. Deadheading spent flowers can prolong the blooming period and prevent unwanted self-seeding. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to make cuts at a 45-degree angle just above a node, promoting better healing and new shoot development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Smooth Ironweed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Smooth Ironweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Vernonia fasciculata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17338,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia lavanduloides, commonly known as lavender sage, prefers moderately moist soil but is drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant thoroughly when the soil feels dry about an inch below the surface. Avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During dry and hot spells, increase the frequency of watering. However, ensure good drainage in the pot or garden bed to prevent standing water. During the plant's dormant period in winter, reduce watering further since the plant's water needs are lower."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia lavanduloides thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. Plant it in a south-facing location if possible, to maximize sun exposure. Although it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight can lead to reduced flowering and a less vigorous plant. In very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from the extreme heat, preventing scorching and helping conserve soil moisture."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia lavanduloides helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier, vigorous growth. Prune back the plant in early spring just as new growth begins to appear. Cut stems back to about one-third of their previous height, removing any dead, damaged, or weak branches to promote good air circulation. During the growing season, deadhead spent flowers to encourage further blooming and to prevent the plant from becoming leggy. In late autumn, a light trim can tidy up the plant before winter."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lavender Leaf Sage","description":"Salvia lavanduloides, the lavender leaf sage, is a species of flowering plant in the family Lamiaceae, native to Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, and Costa Rica. Found in montane forests, it is fire-adapted.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Lavender Leaf Sage"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Salvia lavanduloides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17834,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solanum tridynamum, like many plants, requires consistent but moderate watering. It is important to ensure the soil stays slightly moist but not waterlogged, as overly wet soil can lead to root rot. Water the plant once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the growing season, you might need to water more frequently, but reduce the amount during the winter when the plant's growth slows. Always use water that is at room temperature to avoid shocking the plant's roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solanum tridynamum prefers environments with bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight can damage the foliage by causing leaf scorch, so it’s best to place the plant where it can receive morning sun and protection from the harsh afternoon rays. If indoor, choose a spot near a window that provides plenty of filtered light. If the plant doesn't seem to be thriving, you might need to adjust its lighting conditions. Remember, insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and a lack of flowering, so aim for balanced light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solanum tridynamum should be done to encourage a bushier growth pattern and remove any dead or damaged leaves or stems. The best time to prune is during spring or early summer. Use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to make clean cuts, reducing the risk of disease. Focus on cutting back overly long stems and any parts that appear unhealthy. Regular pruning promotes better light penetration and can improve the plant's overall vigor. Be sure to remove any suckers growing from the base to maintain the plant's desired shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sierra Madre nightshade","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Sierra Madre nightshade"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Solanum tridynamum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16644,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Melastoma malabathricum, commonly known as the Singapore rhododendron or Malabar melastome, prefers consistently moist soil. Water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil is evenly moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season in spring and summer, increased watering may be necessary, while in winter, reduce the frequency slightly. The soil should be well-draining to prevent root rot, and it is beneficial to allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to maintain proper moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Melastoma malabathricum thrives in full to partial sunlight. It prefers bright, indirect light, although it can tolerate some direct morning sun. In hotter climates, it is advisable to protect the plant from the scorching midday and afternoon sun to prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors, position the plant near a window where it can receive filtered light or supplement with artificial lighting if natural light is insufficient. Adequate sunlight is essential for its growth, flowering, and development of vibrant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Melastoma malabathricum involves removing dead or damaged stems and shaping the plant to encourage a bushier growth habit. This should ideally be done after the flowering period to avoid cutting off potential blooms. Light pruning can maintain its size and shape, and to remove any competing shoots or suckers that may arise at the base. Avoid cutting back too harshly as this can stress the plant. Regular pruning helps improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, promoting healthier growth and increased flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Malabar Melastome","description":"Melastoma malabathricum, known also as Malabar melastome, Indian rhododendron, Singapore rhododendron and senduduk, is a flowering plant in the family Melastomataceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Dark purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["India","Sri Lanka","Malaysia","Indonesia","Australia"],"other_name":["Malabar Melastome"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Melastoma malabathricum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16443,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gliricidia sepium is a resilient plant that doesn't require extensive watering once it is established. Initially, it should be watered regularly to help the root system set in. Once grown, this plant tolerates drought conditions well, so watering can be reduced significantly, especially in regions with moderate rainfall. It's important to avoid overwatering as Gliricidia prefers dry to moderately moist soil conditions. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent root rot and ensure the plant remains healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gliricidia sepium thrives best in full sunlight, which is essential for its growth and flowering. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. It can tolerate partial shade, but this may result in reduced flowering and a less dense foliage structure. Planting Gliricidia in an open area where it can receive abundant sunlight will ensure it grows vigorously and maintains its vibrant health. Additionally, full sun exposure can help the plant's ability to fix nitrogen, enhancing soil fertility around it."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gliricidia sepium should be performed primarily to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Pruning can be done after the flowering period, typically in late spring to early summer. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve aeration and prevent pest infestation. It's also advised to trim back any excessively long branches to encourage denser foliage growth, which can enhance its utility as a hedge or shade provider. Regular pruning every year or two can help manage the plant's height and spread, ensuring it remains manageable and healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fence Post Tree","description":"Gliricidia sepium, often simply referred to as Gliricidia (common names: quickstick, mata ratón; cacao de nance, cachanance; piñon Cubano in the Dominican Republic; madreado in Honduras; kakawate in the Philippines; madre xacao or madre de cacao in the Philippines and Guatemala; and madero negro in Nicaragua); wetahiriya in Sinhala ,is a medium size leguminous tree belonging to the family Fabaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Central America","Mexico"],"other_name":["Fence Post Tree"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Gliricidia sepium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17237,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Stenanthium densum, commonly known as Osceola's plume, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. It is essential to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer. However, be cautious not to overwater, as the plant does not thrive in waterlogged conditions. Reduce watering in the fall and winter months when the plant is dormant. Using organic mulch can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature, providing a suitable environment for the plant's roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Stenanthium densum thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from the intense sun, which may cause leaf scorching. In cooler regions, a position with full sun exposure is ideal to ensure robust growth and abundant flowering. If grown in partial shade, ensure it still receives sufficient light, as overly shaded conditions can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Stenanthium densum is primarily focused on removing dead or damaged foliage and spent flower stalks to encourage healthy growth and improve the plant's appearance. It is best to prune after the flowering season, typically in late fall. Cut back the dead flower stalks to the base of the plant. If any stems or leaves appear discolored or unhealthy, trim them back to healthy tissue. Regularly cleaning up the plant not only helps maintain its aesthetic appeal but also reduces the risk of disease spreading."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Osceola's plume","description":"Stenanthium densum is a poisonous but spectacular monocot wildflower native to pine barrens of the eastern United States. Stenanthium leimanthoides is either treated as a synonym of this species or as a separate species. It is known variously as Osceola's plume, crowpoison, or black snakeroot.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Osceola's plume"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Stenanthium densum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17041,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Symphoricarpos microphyllus, commonly known as the small-leaved snowberry, prefers moderate watering, particularly during its initial growth phase. Once established, it is quite drought-tolerant but benefits from occasional deep watering during extended dry spells to keep the soil slightly moist. It's important to avoid waterlogging, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. Therefore, ensure the planting area has well-drained soil to maintain the health of the plant. Adjust watering frequency based on weather conditions, providing more water in hot, dry climates and less during cooler, rainy periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Symphoricarpos microphyllus thrives in full sun to partial shade. It can tolerate a range of light conditions but performs best when it receives at least four to six hours of direct sunlight each day. If planted in areas with high temperatures, providing some afternoon shade can help minimize stress on the plant. While it can grow in partial shade, less sunlight may result in reduced flowering and berry production, so it's ideal to plant it in a location where it receives ample sunlight for optimal growth and fruiting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not heavily required for Symphoricarpos microphyllus, but occasional trimming can enhance its shape and promote denser growth. It's best to prune the plant in late winter to early spring, before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches to improve airflow and light penetration within the plant. Additionally, thinning out crowded areas helps maintain a tidy appearance and can reduce the risk of disease. For older plants, rejuvenation pruning by cutting back about one-third of the oldest stems to ground level can encourage new, vigorous growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pink Snowberry","description":"Symphoricarpos microphyllus, the pink snowberry, is a North American species of flowering plant in the honeysuckle family. It is widespread across much of Mexico from Chihuahua to Chiapas, and found also in Guatemala, Honduras, and the US State of New Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Pink Snowberry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Symphoricarpos microphyllus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Thinning the canopy can also improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, reducing the risk of diseases. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season as this can stress the tree. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17635,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dibaeis absoluta, a type of lichen, typically requires minimal watering when grown in captivity, as it draws most of its moisture from the environment. In cultivation, such as when kept in a terrarium, it's important to simulate its natural habitat by maintaining a moderate level of humidity. Overwatering can be harmful, as lichens are highly sensitive to excess moisture which can lead to mold or decay. Spritz with water occasionally or maintain a humid environment, but ensure that there's adequate air circulation to prevent fungal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dibaeis absoluta thrives in indirect light, as direct sunlight can be too intense and may dry out the lichen or cause burning. Ideally, place it in a location that receives ample indirect sunlight, mimicking its natural environment in forests or on rocky surfaces where it would experience dappled or filtered light. If indoors, a north or east-facing window can provide appropriate lighting conditions. Avoid placing it in complete darkness, as adequate light is necessary for its photosynthetic processes and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a lichen, Dibaeis absoluta doesn't require pruning like typical plants do. Instead, care should focus on maintaining its health by removing any decomposed or dead portions that might appear on its surface. However, if cultivated in a garden setting, it is crucial to mimic its natural habitat by ensuring consistent moisture. Regular watering, allowing the soil to remain slightly damp but not waterlogged, is key. Be cautious of overwatering, as standing water can harm the plant. Adjust watering frequency based on environmental conditions and soil drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salicornia europaea prefers full sun exposure for optimal growth, making it crucial to provide plenty of direct sunlight when cultivating this plant. It thrives best in environments where it can receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In situations where natural light is limited, supplementary grow lights can help support its growth, ensuring that it receives the light levels necessary for robust development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salicornia europaea is generally minimal, as it naturally maintains a tidy appearance. However, you can promote healthier growth by removing any dead or damaged stems throughout its growing season. Cleanly cut back dead or decaying parts in late autumn for tidiness."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Glasswort","description":"Salicornia europaea , known as common glasswort or just glasswort, is a halophytic annual dicot which grows in various zones of intertidal salt marshes. Keep in shaded but well-lit environments to ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Tillandsia imperialis mainly involves removing dead or dried leaves rather than regular trims. Gently pull away any dead leaves from the base, being careful not to damage the healthy parts. This upkeep helps maintain a neat appearance and encourages new growth, ensuring your air plant remains healthy and aesthetically pleasing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"imperial airplant","description":"Tillandsia imperialis is a species in the genus Tillandsia. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17835,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agave potatorum requires very little water and is drought tolerant. It thrives in dry conditions and should be watered sparingly, especially during the colder months. Allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. In general, watering every two to three weeks during the growing season (spring and summer) is sufficient. In winter, reduce watering to once a month. Overwatering is the most common issue faced by agave plants, so err on the side of underwatering rather than overwatering. Use well-draining soil to ensure excess moisture is quickly wicked away."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agave potatorum thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to maintain its compact size and vibrant color. In climates with extremely hot summers, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch. While it can tolerate some shade, prolonged low-light conditions can lead to leggy, weak growth. For indoor cultivation, place it near a south- or west-facing window where it can receive bright light. Adequate sunlight is crucial for healthy growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agave potatorum is not typically necessary, except for removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance. Use a sharp, sterilized knife or pruning shears to cut the leaves as close to the base as possible. Take care to protect yourself from the sharp spines along the leaf edges. Pruning should be done during the plant's dormant period in the cooler months to provide minimal stress. Always prune with consideration of the plant's natural shape, avoiding excessive trimming that might hinder its growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Butterfly Agave","description":"Agave potatorum, the Verschaffelt agave, is a species of flowering plant in the family Asparagaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16246,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cotoneaster lucidus prefers well-drained soil that is kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. It is drought-tolerant once established, but during the first growing season, regular watering is essential to help establish a deep root system. Water the plant deeply at the base, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Overwatering or poor drainage can lead to root rot. During dry periods or in hot climates, increase the watering frequency slightly to maintain the plant's health and appearance."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cotoneaster lucidus thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers at least six hours of sunlight per day for optimal growth and berry production. In shadier locations, you might notice fewer flowers and berries, and the plant may grow more sparsely. If grown as part of a mixed border, ensure it isn’t overshadowed by taller plants. In particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and reduce the need for frequent irrigation. Adjust the planting location based on your regional climate for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cotoneaster lucidus is important to maintain its shape and encourage denser growth. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring before new growth starts. Begin by removing any dead, diseased, or crossing branches. You can then shape the shrub to your desired form, whether it's a hedge or more natural shape. Regular light pruning encourages a more compact growth and can enhance flowering and berry production. Be cautious not to remove more than one-third of the plant at once to avoid stressing it."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Shiny Cotoneaster","description":"Cotoneaster lucidus, the shiny cotoneaster, or hedge cotoneaster, is a deciduous, medium-sized shrub with long, spreading branches reaching heights (and breadths) of 6' to 10'. It is native to parts of northern Asia, and adapted to tolerate colder weather (to zone 4). C. lucidus was described in 1856 by Diederich Franz Leonhard von Schlechtendal.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Asia"],"other_name":["Shiny Cotoneaster"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Fireblight"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cotoneaster lucidus"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After flowering, you can trim spent flower spikes to tidy the plant. Use sterilized cutting tools to prevent disease from spreading. It’s also beneficial to remove any shriveled or dead pseudobulbs. Keep an eye out for pests and clean up any plant debris that could harbor them."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Florida butterfly orchid","description":"Encyclia tampensis (Encyclia from Greek - enkykleoma \"to encircle\" and tampensis - \"Tampa\") or Tampa butterfly orchid is a species of flowering plant in the Orchid family, subfamily Epidendroideae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Florida","Cuba","Bahamas"],"other_name":["Florida butterfly orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Encyclia tampensis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to keep the soil consistently moist during the growing season, especially in dry spells, but avoid over-watering as this can lead to root rot. Ensure the top inch of soil dries out between waterings. During the dormant period in late summer, reduce watering to prevent waterlogging while keeping the soil slightly moist. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and alleviate temperature fluctuations, maintaining a stable environment for the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Iris verna thrives best in full sun conditions, which contribute to optimal blooming and vibrant flower colors. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. In regions with particularly hot summers, the plant can tolerate light shade, especially in the afternoon, to protect the delicate flowers and retain moisture. If grown in partial shade, the iris may have fewer blooms and a leggier growth. Ensuring proper sunlight exposure will not only contribute to the plant's overall health but also enhance its aesthetic appeal in a garden setting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Iris verna should be done carefully to maintain the plant’s health and appearance. After the flowering period, which usually occurs in early spring, remove spent blooms to encourage plant vigor and prevent seed formation, which can divert energy from the plant. In late fall, once the foliage begins to die back naturally, trim the leaves back to just above the rhizome to tidy up the garden and prevent disease. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent injury or disease transmission. Regularly inspect the plant for any dead or damaged parts and remove them promptly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dwarf Iris","description":"Iris verna is a species of iris in the family Iridaceae, also in the subgenus of Iris. After the flowering period in late summer, lightly trim back the plant to encourage bushier growth and remove spent blooms, which will help prolong blooming and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. It's best to place Mammillaria rhodantha in a location that receives full sun for at least 4-6 hours a day, such as a south-facing window. Insufficient sunlight will result in weak growth and loss of its natural compact shape, so ensuring ample light is crucial for its health and appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mammillaria rhodantha is generally minimal as it is a slow-growing cactus. Pruning is mainly for maintaining the plant’s shape or removing any dead or damaged parts. Use sterilized tools to prevent infections, and safely handle this spiny cactus with gloves. If offsets (pups) appear and you're aiming for propagation, they can be carefully removed using a sharp knife. Allow any cut surfaces to callous over for a few days before potting, which helps prevent rot when placed in the soil."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rainbow Pincushion","description":"Mammillaria rhodantha (common name rainbow pincushion) is a plant in the cactus family (Cactaceae) and is one of 171 species in the genus Mammillaria which are characterized by having nipple-shaped tubercles or prominences on their surface.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Rainbow Pincushion"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Mammillaria rhodantha"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17340,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Helichrysum arenarium, commonly known as the \"dwarf everlast\", prefers moderate watering. It's important to allow the soil to dry out between waterings, as the plant is drought-tolerant and sensitive to overwatering which can lead to root rot. In the growing seasons of spring and summer, you can water it once a week, depending on humidity levels and temperature. During fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, as the plant is in its dormant phase and requires less moisture. Make sure the container has good drainage to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helichrysum arenarium thrives in full sun conditions. It requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day to grow optimally. Planting it in a location that receives morning and early afternoon sun is ideal. If growing indoors, place it by the brightest window available or consider supplementing with a grow light to ensure adequate light exposure. Insufficient sunlight can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering, so ensuring proper sunlight is crucial for its well-being."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helichrysum arenarium should be done to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. In early spring, before new growth begins, remove any dead or damaged stems. Trim back any excessively long branches to promote a bushier appearance. After the flowering period, you can deadhead spent blooms to tidy the plant and possibly encourage a second bloom. Be careful not to cut too much of the healthy foliage as it can interfere with the plant's ability to photosynthesize and thrive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dwarf Everlasting","description":"Helichrysum arenarium is also known as dwarf everlast, and as immortelle.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Dwarf Everlasting"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Helichrysum arenarium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16646,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Melica mutica, or the two-flowered melicgrass, generally thrives in moist environments but is tolerant of some dry conditions once established. Regular watering is essential during the first growing season to develop a strong root system. After establishment, water the plant moderately, allowing the top two inches of soil to dry out between waterings. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Monitoring rainfall and local climate conditions can assist in determining the necessary frequency of supplemental watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Melica mutica prefers a habitat with partial to full sun exposure. Ideally, it should receive at least 4–6 hours of sunlight each day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent overstressing the plant. However, too much shade will result in diminished growth and fewer flowers. If you are cultivating Melica mutica indoors or in a greenhouse setting, ensure that it is positioned near a south-facing window or under grow lights to fulfill its light requirements adequately."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Melica mutica is generally minimal but can be beneficial for maintaining a tidy appearance and promoting vigorous growth. During the late winter or early spring, before new growth emerges, gently trim back any dead or damaged stems to the base of the plant. Additionally, removing spent flowering stalks after bloom can help prevent self-seeding if this is undesirable. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant, and be sure to leave healthy foliage intact to allow photosynthesis to continue efficiently."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Twoflower Melicgrass","description":"Melica mutica, twoflower melicgrass, is a grass species in the Poaceae family that can be found in southeastern United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Twoflower Melicgrass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Melica mutica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17142,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vernonia missurica, commonly known as Missouri Ironweed, prefers consistent moisture and performs best when the soil remains evenly damp. However, while it tolerates periods of drought, it thrives with regular watering, especially during prolonged dry spells. It's important not to overwater, so ensuring the soil has good drainage will prevent root rot. Regular watering during the growing season helps the plant maintain its strong, vibrant growth. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering to prevent excess moisture as the plant does not require much water when it is not actively growing."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Missouri Ironweed (Vernonia missurica) thrives best in full sun, which allows it to produce its iconic striking purple blooms. Planting it in an area that receives at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day will ensure healthy growth and a robust flowering display. While it can tolerate partial shade, particularly during the hottest part of the day, too little sunlight may lead to fewer blooms and a leggier plant structure. Therefore, for optimal health and flowering, choose a sunny spot in your garden for this plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vernonia missurica can help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. For best results, prune in early spring before new growth begins. Cutting back the previous year's stems to a height of about 6-12 inches helps rejuvenate the plant. Deadheading flowers after they bloom will not only keep the plant tidy but can also promote repeat flowering. However, leaving some seed heads through the winter can provide an interesting texture to the garden and offer food for birds. Overall, light pruning and deadheading are usually sufficient for this hardy perennial."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Missouri Ironweed","description":"Vernonia missurica, the Missouri ironweed, is a species of purple colored perennial plant from Asteraceae family that can be found growing in the central United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Missouri Ironweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Vernonia missurica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is particularly drought-tolerant once established, so in many climates, rainwater is enough at times. Be cautious not to waterlog the soil, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. During the growing season in the spring and summer, water thoroughly but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry completely between waterings. In general, watering once every two weeks should suffice, depending on humidity and temperature. In winter, reduce watering significantly or stop altogether, as the cactus enters dormancy. Overwatering is a common mistake, so ensure the cactus is planted in well-draining soil, and always check that the topsoil is dry before the next watering session."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thelocactus rinconensis thrives in bright sunlight and should be placed where it receives full sun for at least six hours a day. This exposure helps it maintain its compact shape and encourages healthy growth and flowering. Although it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight can lead to elongated stems and weakened plants. If keeping it indoors, place it near a south-facing window or use a grow light to supplement natural light. Gradually acclimate the cactus if moving it to more intense light to prevent sunburn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Thelocactus rinconensis is minimal, mainly involving the removal of dead or damaged parts. This cactus does not require regular pruning for shape or growth. If you notice any shriveled or rotting parts, use sterilized scissors or a knife to carefully cut these away to prevent disease. Occasionally, offsets or pups may form around the base of the plant. These can be removed to propagate new plants or left to grow naturally. Always wear gloves when handling this cactus to avoid injury from its sharp spines."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Thelocactus rinconensis is a species of cactus. Pruning can help prevent the plant from becoming too invasive and encourage a denser habit. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17837,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agave xylonacantha is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. Water the plant deeply every 2-4 weeks during the growing season (spring and summer) and reduce watering significantly during the fall and winter when the plant becomes dormant. Make sure the soil dries out completely between watering to prevent root rot. Overwatering is more harmful than underwatering for this species, so it's important to ensure that the plant is not sitting in water and that the pot has proper drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agave xylonacantha thrives best in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. It requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day to maintain its compact shape and vibrant leaf color. When grown indoors, place the plant in the sunniest spot available, such as a south or west-facing window. If you're transitioning the plant from indoors to outdoors, do so gradually to prevent sunburn. Providing adequate sunlight also enhances the plant's resistance to pests and diseases, promoting overall health and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Agave xylonacantha is mostly focused on removing damaged or dead leaves. Use a sharp, sterilized knife or garden shears to trim off the spent leaves close to the base without damaging the healthy leaves. Be cautious of the sharp spines on the leaf edges, and wear gloves and protective clothing to prevent injury. Pruning should be limited, as agaves do not require frequent cutting, and excessive pruning could stress the plant. Remove any flowers that appear, unless you wish for seed production, as flowering can lead to the plant's death (monocarpic habit)."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Agave xylonacantha is a plant species native to Hidalgo, Tamaulipas, Guanajuato and Queretaro in Mexico, but commonly cultivated as an ornamental on other regions. A. xylonacantha is an easy-to-grow member of the genus Agave.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Snout Weevil"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Offsets"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Agave xylonacantha"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17442,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ligustrum quihoui, commonly known as Waxleaf Privet, prefers moderately moist soil but can tolerate occasional drought once established. It's best to water the plant deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth. Ensure the soil drains well to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During hot or dry spells, increase watering frequency, but always check the topsoil to ensure it has dried out slightly before the next watering. Reduce watering in the cooler months when the plant is not actively growing."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ligustrum quihoui thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight daily to maintain its dense foliage and optimal growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, the plant might become leggy and produce fewer flowers. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect it from the harshest sunlight hours, preventing leaf scorch and promoting healthier growth. Ensure it's planted in a spot with ample light for the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ligustrum quihoui is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to prevent disease. You can also shape the plant to maintain the desired height and density. Regular trimming will help maintain its compact form and promote a bushier appearance. Be careful not to remove more than one-third of the plant at a time to avoid stressing it."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Quihoui privet","description":"Ligustrum quihoui (waxyleaf privet, 小叶女贞 xiao ye nu zhen) is a shrub native to Korea and China (Anhui, Guizhou, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu, Jiangxi, Shaanxi, Shandong, Sichuan, Xizang (Tibet), Yunnan, Zhejiang). As with some other members of the genus, L. quihoui is cultivated as an ornamental in many places and has become naturalized and invasive in urban areas and scattered forested locales of the southeastern United States (Texas, Oklahoma, Alabama, Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, North Carolina, Virginia, Maryland).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China"],"other_name":["Quihoui privet"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ligustrum quihoui"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17240,"attracts":["Hummingbirds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crocosmia × crocosmiiflora prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. Water the plant deeply once a week during periods of active growth, especially in the hot summer months. Ensure the soil remains moist, but avoid waterlogging which can lead to root rot. Reduce watering in the fall once the flowering season ends and allow the soil to dry slightly between watering sessions in the winter when the plant is dormant. Mulching can help retain soil moisture. Adjust watering frequency depending on rainfall and soil type to help maintain optimal growth conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crocosmia × crocosmiiflora thrives best in full sun but can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates. Ideally, provide at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal blooming and growth. In cooler climates, more sun is necessary to ensure robust flowering, whereas in extremely hot regions, some afternoon shade could prevent scorching. If planted in too much shade, the plant may produce fewer flowers. Positioning this plant in a garden with good morning sun can promote vibrant blooms and healthy foliage throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crocosmia × crocosmiiflora is straightforward and helps maintain the plant's aesthetic and health. After flowering, remove spent flower stalks to prevent unnecessary energy expenditure on seed production. In late fall or early winter, cut back the foliage to ground level once it yellows and dies back naturally, aiding in tidiness and reducing overwintering pests. Be careful not to remove green leaves prematurely, as these contribute to photosynthesis and storage of nutrients in the corms for the next blooming season. Divide clumps every 3-4 years to prevent overcrowding."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Garden Montbretia","description":"Crocosmia × crocosmiiflora is a garden hybrid of C. aurea and C. pottsii, first bred 1880 in France by Victor Lemoine. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16941,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sabal mexicana, also known as the Texas palmetto or Mexican palmetto, prefers moist but well-drained soil. It is relatively drought-tolerant once established, but regular watering is beneficial for young palms. Ensure the soil is moist during the growing season, but avoid waterlogging, which can damage the roots. Water deeply and allow the top soil to dry out between waterings. Reduce watering frequency during the cooler months when the plant's growth slows down. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and protect the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sabal mexicana thrives in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade conditions, though growth may be slower. Ideally, this palm should be planted in a location where it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. In regions with very intense sunlight, especially younger plants can benefit from partial shade during the hottest part of the day. Ensure it is not placed in a completely shaded area, as insufficient light can lead to poor growth and a less robust plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Sabal mexicana is minimal and mostly involves removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain its appearance and prevent any potential pest issues. Generally, this should be done at the base of the frond, close to the trunk. Avoid cutting healthy, green fronds as these are crucial for photosynthesis and overall growth. It’s best to prune during the spring or early summer when the plant is actively growing. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease and make clean cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mexican Palmetto","description":"Sabal mexicana is a species of palm tree that is native to North America. Common names include Rio Grande palmetto, Mexican palmetto, Texas palmetto, Texas sabal palm, palmmetto cabbage and palma de mícharos. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16846,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pluchea carolinensis, commonly known as marsh fleabane, prefers a consistent moisture level in its soil, mimicking its natural marshland habitat. It's important to ensure the soil remains slightly damp but not waterlogged, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. A general rule is to water the plant thoroughly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out before the next watering. During hotter months, you may need to water more frequently, while in cooler months, ensure the soil remains just moist enough to sustain growth without oversaturation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pluchea carolinensis thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure optimal growth and blooming. If placed in partial shade, make sure it still gets bright, indirect sunlight to support its development. In regions with intense midday sun, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching. Monitoring the plant for signs of insufficient light, such as leggy growth or fewer blooms, can help you adjust its placement to ensure adequate sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is an essential part of caring for Pluchea carolinensis to maintain its shape and prevent it from becoming too unruly. Regularly removing dead or diseased stems and leaves can promote healthier growth and improve air circulation. You can also cut back overgrown branches to encourage new, denser growth. The best time to prune is during the growing season, from spring to early fall, avoiding pruning during dormancy in the winter months, as this plant can be sensitive to drastic changes in colder conditions."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Cure-for-all","description":"Pluchea carolinensis is a plant in the genus Pluchea.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Caribbean","Central America","Florida","South America"],"other_name":["Cure-for-all"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Pluchea carolinensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16647,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Melicoccus bijugatus, commonly known as Spanish lime or Genip, prefers consistent moisture without becoming waterlogged. Water the plant regularly, ensuring that the soil remains evenly moist, especially during dry periods. However, allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. This tree can tolerate short periods of drought once established, but it performs best with adequate hydration. Be mindful of seasonal changes in moisture requirements; reduce watering in cooler months when the plant's growth slows down. Always use well-draining soil to help prevent overwatering issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Melicoccus bijugatus thrives in full sun or partial shade, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to produce abundant fruit. The tree prefers a sunny location, which helps in encouraging vigorous growth and fruit production. In regions with extremely hot climates, a bit of afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense heat. However, young plants may benefit from filtered sunlight to prevent leaf scorch until they are well established. When planting, choose a spot that can accommodate its eventual size, ensuring it receives adequate sunlight as it matures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Melicoccus bijugatus helps maintain its shape, removes dead or damaged branches, and encourages healthy growth. The best time to prune is during the dormant period after the fruiting season. Remove any crossing or crowded branches to improve air circulation. Trim back longer branches to keep the tree from becoming too tall and to encourage a bushier structure. Be cautious not to over-prune, as this can stress the tree. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, reducing the risk of disease. Regular light pruning throughout the year can help maintain its shape and health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Genip","description":"Melicoccus bijugatus, commonly called Spanish lime, genip, guinep, genipe, ginepa, quenepa, quenepe, chenet, canepa, mamón, limoncillo, skinip, kinnip, \"It is known as huaya in Campeche and Mérida,\" ackee in St.Lucia, St. Vincent & the Grenadines, and Barbados, or mamoncillo. It is a fruit-bearing tree in the soapberry family Sapindaceae, native or naturalized across the New World tropics including South and Central America, and parts of the Caribbean.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Caribbean","South America"],"other_name":["Genip"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects","Mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Melicoccus bijugatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16445,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gymnocarpium robertianum, commonly known as the limestone fern, prefers consistently moist soil without being waterlogged. During dry spells, supplemental watering is beneficial to maintain an evenly moist substrate. It's important to ensure that the water drains well, as stagnant water can cause root rot. Overwatering should be avoided by allowing the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and keep the roots cool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gymnocarpium robertianum thrives in partial to full shade, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. It can tolerate some early morning sun but should be protected from the harsh afternoon rays, which can scorch its delicate fronds. Placement under a canopy of trees or in a shaded garden nook is ideal. If growing indoors, a location with indirect light or a north-facing window is suitable. Excessive direct sunlight will harm its foliage, while too little light can hinder its growth. Monitoring the plant's response to its light environment is crucial for maintaining its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gymnocarpium robertianum mainly involves removing dead or damaged fronds to encourage healthy growth and maintain a tidy appearance. This should ideally be done in the early spring before the new fronds start to emerge. Gently cut the old fronds at soil level using sharp, clean scissors or shears. Regularly check for any diseased or pest-infested parts and remove them promptly to prevent spreading. Minimal pruning is usually necessary as this fern forms a natural and appealing shape that requires little intervention. Avoid excessive trimming to preserve its delicate, airy structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"limestone oak fern","description":"Gymnocarpium robertianum, the limestone fern or scented oakfern, is a fern of the family Cystopteridaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","western Asia"],"other_name":["limestone oak fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Gymnocarpium robertianum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16248,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crassocephalum crepidioides, commonly known as fireweed, prefers consistently moist soil but doesn't like to be waterlogged. It is best to water this plant regularly, ensuring the soil stays evenly moist. However, make sure the water drains well to prevent root rot. For indoor plants, water them thoroughly until water flows out of the drainage holes, then let the top inch of the soil dry out before watering again. In their natural habitat, these plants may receive ample rain, so mimic similar conditions for optimal growth. Adjust the watering frequency based on humidity levels and seasonal changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crassocephalum crepidioides thrives in bright, indirect sunlight to partial shade. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially during early morning or late afternoon, excessive exposure to harsh midday sun may scorch its leaves. Ideally, place the plant where it can receive filtered light through sheer curtains or dappled sunlight underneath a larger plant. If cultivated indoors, positioning it near a north or east-facing window would be ideal. Adjust light exposure to ensure vibrant growth and check for signs of sunburn or leggy growth to modify its placement accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassocephalum crepidioides is not overly demanding, but it helps in maintaining a healthy plant. Regularly removing dead or yellowing leaves is essential to prevent disease and promote air circulation. Pinch back the tips to encourage bushier growth and to prevent the plant from becoming leggy. If the plant blooms, deadhead the flowers once they fade to keep the plant looking tidy and to extend the blooming period. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruners to make cuts to avoid damaging the plant tissue."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"redflower ragleaf","description":"Crassocephalum crepidioides, also called ebolo, thickhead, redflower ragleaf, or fireweed, is an erect annual slightly succulent herb growing up to 180 cm tall. Its use is widespread in many tropical and subtropical regions, but is especially prominent in tropical Africa. Its fleshy, mucilaginous leaves and stems are eaten as a vegetable, and many parts of the plant have medical uses. However, the safety of internal use needs further research due to the presence of plant toxins....","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Tropical Africa"],"other_name":["redflower ragleaf"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Crassocephalum crepidioides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16446,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gymnocladus dioicus, commonly known as the Kentucky Coffeetree, is a drought-resistant species requiring minimal watering once established. During its initial growth phase, regular watering is essential to develop a robust root system, usually about once a week, ensuring the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. As it matures, reduce watering frequency since this tree thrives in well-drained soils and can tolerate dry conditions. During prolonged dry spells, occasional deep watering encourages deeper root growth, enhancing drought resistance. Always allow the topsoil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent over-saturation and root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gymnocladus dioicus thrives best in full sunlight, meaning it requires at least six hours of direct light each day to grow optimally. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun ensures vigorous growth and overall health. This tree's large stature and architectural form benefit from ample sunlight to develop its dense and attractive foliage during the growing season. Positioning it in an open area not only meets its sunlight needs but also allows it to spread naturally. In shaded conditions, the tree may exhibit slower growth and reduced foliage density, affecting its ornamental appeal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gymnocladus dioicus should be done during the late winter or early spring while the tree is dormant, before new growth begins. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or crossing branches to maintain a healthy structure and promote better air circulation within the canopy. It's also beneficial to prune any suckers or low-hanging branches early to encourage a strong, central leader. Minimal pruning is generally required for this tree, as it naturally develops an open, airy crown. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. It can tolerate some direct sun, especially in the morning or late afternoon, but too much direct sunlight can scorch its leaves. Ideally, place it in a position where it receives light filtered through a curtain or dappled sunlight. If kept indoors, a position near an east or south-facing window would be ideal. During the winter months or in particularly low-light environments, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure uniform growth and avoid leaning towards the light source."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Justicia pilosella helps maintain a bushy shape and encourages healthier growth. The best time to prune is during the growing season, in spring or early summer. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems to prevent the spread of infections. Prune back overgrown branches to maintain a balanced shape and promote airflow through the plant's center. Pinching back new growth can encourage the plant to become fuller. Use clean, sharp tools to minimize damage to the plant. Regular pruning will help control the plant's size and shape, making it more aesthetically pleasing and ensuring vigorous growth. "}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Gregg's tube tongue","description":"Justicia pilosella (syns. It is native to New Mexico, Texas, and east-central Mexico. A perennial herb reaching 1 ft (30 cm), it is typically found growing in clearings and forest edges in rocky or gravelly soils.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Gregg's tube tongue"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Justicia pilosella"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If growing in an area with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from excessive heat stress. Adjust the plant's exposure accordingly to strike a balance between sunlight and protection from harsh conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sabatia calycina is typically minimal, primarily because it is a wildflower that thrives with little intervention. However, to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage a second bloom, you can deadhead spent flowers by cutting the flower stalks back to a lateral bud or leaf. This will help prevent the plant from setting seed and encourage bushier growth. At the end of the growing season, you may also remove any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth in the next season. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17044,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Symphyotrichum ciliolatum, commonly known as fringed blue aster, prefers moderate watering. It thrives in well-drained soil, so ensure the soil is kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, water the plant deeply once a week, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions. Reduce the watering frequency during the winter months when the plant is dormant, ensuring that the soil is not too dry or too soggy, as either condition can stress the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Symphyotrichum ciliolatum thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, provide at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching. If planted in shadier areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer blooms. While it can tolerate some shade, performance and flowering will be better with more sunlight. Consider the local climate when positioning to ensure it receives adequate light without extreme heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Symphyotrichum ciliolatum involves removing spent flowers and dead or damaged stems, which encourages healthy growth and blooms. Prune the plant in the spring to remove any winter damage and in late summer, if necessary, to maintain shape and size. After flowering in the fall, cutting back the stems to ground level can promote vigorous growth in the next season. However, leaving some stems through winter can provide habitats for beneficial insects. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid disease transmission and ensure a clean cut."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lindley's Aster","description":"Symphyotrichum ciliolatum (formerly Aster ciliolatus), commonly known as Lindley's aster or fringed blue aster, is a perennial herb native to Canada and the northern United States. It is also known as ciliolate (wood) aster or northern heart-leaved aster. The common name \"Lindley's aster\" honours John Lindley who first described the species in 1834.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Lindley's Aster"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Symphyotrichum ciliolatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17342,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hygrocybe miniata, commonly known as the vermilion waxcap, is a type of wild mushroom and not a plant that requires intentional watering like houseplants. These fungi generally thrive in moist, humid conditions found naturally in their environment. If you are cultivating these mushrooms, ensure their growing environment maintains adequate moisture. This can be achieved through misting or providing a consistently damp substrate, aligning with their natural preference for wet, grassy habitats. Care should be taken not to overwater, as excessive moisture may lead to rot or other fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hygrocybe miniata typically grows in grassy, mossy areas in woodlands and prefers dappled sunlight, similar to the filtered light found naturally under a canopy of trees. They do not thrive under direct, harsh sunlight, which can dry out their environment. If cultivating, aim to simulate these conditions by placing them where they receive some indirect sunlight or filtered light during the day. Balanced light helps support their growth by preventing excessive moisture loss while providing enough warmth for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Hygrocybe miniata does not require pruning in the traditional sense like woody plants or perennials. Since it is a mushroom, grooming or pruning is not applicable. However, if you are managing these mushrooms in a garden or controlled environment, removing old or decaying mushrooms can help prevent the spread of diseases and maintain overall health of the area. Simply removing them by hand should suffice, and it is a good practice to dispose of them properly to avoid any potential spread of spores that could cause issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Vermilion Waxcap","description":"Hygrocybe miniata, commonly known as the vermilion waxcap, is a small, bright red or red-orange mushroom of the waxcap genus Hygrocybe. It is a cosmopolitan species, that is found worldwide. In Europe, it is found in fields, on sandy heaths, or grassy commons in the autumn. It is found in rainforest and eucalypt forest as well as heathland in Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Vermilion Waxcap"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Hygrocybe miniata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17241,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mentha × piperita, commonly known as peppermint, thrives in consistently moist soil. Water the plant regularly to ensure the soil remains damp, but be careful not to overwater as this could lead to root rot. It is crucial to maintain proper drainage to prevent waterlogging. During the hot summer months, you may need to water more frequently to keep the plant healthy. However, during the winter, the watering can be reduced as the plant’s growth slows down. Keeping the soil well-watered without letting it dry out completely is key to successful peppermint cultivation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mentha × piperita prefers full sun to partial shade conditions, ideally receiving around 6 hours of sunlight per day. However, in regions with very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. If growing indoors or in a shady garden area, ensure the plant receives bright, indirect light to thrive. While it is adaptable to various light conditions, optimal peppermint growth and flavor development are achieved with adequate sunlight exposure. Adjust light conditions based on the plant's response and growth pattern."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning is essential for Mentha × piperita to encourage bushy growth and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. Trim back the stems by about one-third, focusing on cutting just above a leaf node to stimulate new growth. This is best done during the growing season in the spring and early summer. Removing any dead or damaged leaves ensures the plant’s energy is directed towards healthy growth. Regular harvesting of the leaves can also serve as pruning and helps to invigorate the plant. Proper pruning also prevents the plant from becoming invasive in garden settings."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Peppermint","description":"Peppermint (Mentha × piperita, also known as Mentha balsamea Willd.) is a hybrid mint, a cross between watermint and spearmint. Indigenous to Europe and the Middle East, the plant is now widespread in cultivation in many regions of the world. It is occasionally found in the wild with its parent species.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Middle East"],"other_name":["Peppermint"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Rust","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Mentha × piperita"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16648,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Melochia pyramidata prefers a balanced watering routine that prevents both drought and waterlogging. The plant thrives in consistently moist but well-drained soil. It is important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions to avoid root rot, especially in potted settings. During the active growing season in spring and summer, watering should be more frequent to support vigorous growth, while in the cooler months, the frequency can be reduced. Rainwater or filtered water is ideal as it minimizes potential mineral buildup, which can harm the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Melochia pyramidata thrives in full sunlight to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. If grown in regions with intense midday sun, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorching. When growing indoors, a south or west-facing window that receives ample light is suitable. However, if natural sunlight is insufficient, supplementing with a grow light can ensure the plant receives adequate light to maintain healthy development and bloom production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Melochia pyramidata involves removing dead or damaged branches and shaping the plant to encourage bushier growth. This plant can be pruned in early spring just before the growing season begins. Trimming back long stems can also help maintain its desired shape and prevent it from becoming too leggy. Regular pruning will promote better air circulation as well as healthier growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts. Additionally, removing spent flowers can stimulate further blooming and maintain the plant's appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pyramid Flower","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Africa","Americas","India"],"other_name":["Pyramid Flower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Whitefly"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Melochia pyramidata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
