{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17940,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tagetes lucida, commonly known as Mexican tarragon, prefers well-drained soil and moderate watering. It's crucial not to overwater this plant, as it is somewhat drought-tolerant once established. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, water consistently but ensure that the plant is not sitting in waterlogged soil. In the winter months, reduce watering frequency as the plant's growth slows down. Observing the plant's leaves is a good indicator: if they start to droop, it's time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tagetes lucida thrives in full sun and requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. It can tolerate partial shade, but the plant may produce fewer flowers. If grown indoors or in areas with limited sunlight, place the plant in the sunniest spot available, such as a south-facing window. Providing sufficient sunlight ensures robust growth and enhances the aromatic qualities of the leaves. In overly hot climates, offering some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from extreme heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tagetes lucida helps maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Regularly pinching back the tips can lead to a fuller, more compact plant. After the flowering period, cutting back the plant by about one-third will remove spent flowers and promote new growth. You can also remove any dead or damaged leaves to help improve air circulation within the plant and maintain its health. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts to prevent disease transmission. Pruning in the early spring is ideal before the plant begins its active growth phase."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mexican Marigold","description":"Tagetes lucida Cav. is a perennial plant native to Mexico and Central America. It is used as a medicinal plant and as a culinary herb. The leaves have a tarragon-like flavor, with hints of anise, and it has entered the nursery trade in North America as a tarragon substitute. Common names include sweetscented marigold', Mexican marigold, Mexican mint marigold, Mexican tarragon, Spanish tarragon, sweet mace, Texas tarragon, pericón, yerbaniz, and hierbanís.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Mexican Marigold"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Tagetes lucida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

You should allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. This species is somewhat drought-tolerant, so it's better to underwater than overwater. During the growing season in spring and summer, water more frequently to keep the soil consistently moist but never soggy. In contrast, reduce watering in the fall and winter months when the plant's growth slows down. Always ensure good drainage in the potting mix or soil to avoid waterlogging, which can be detrimental to the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sairocarpus coulterianus thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day, which will encourage the best flowering and healthiest foliage. Insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. If natural light is inadequate, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights to provide the necessary intensity and duration of light exposure needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sairocarpus coulterianus involves removing spent flowers and trimming back any dead or diseased stems to encourage new growth and maintain a tidy appearance. Deadheading, or cutting off faded blooms, helps the plant to focus its energy on producing new flowers rather than seeds. You can perform a more extensive prune at the end of the flowering season to help shape the plant and promote bushier growth. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts, which aids in faster healing and reduces the risk of disease. Regular monitoring for any signs of pest infestation or disease is also beneficial."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Coulter's snapdragon","description":"Antirrhinum coulterianum (syn. It requires water to cover its roots and rhizome fully, usually to a depth of 6 to 18 inches depending on the plant's size. Ensure the water is clear and free from contaminants. This plant also benefits from routine water changes to prevent stagnation and algal bloom. During winter or off-season, water levels can be lowered to help manage growth and any adverse conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nymphaea nouchali requires full sun to thrive, typically needing around 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. This exposure encourages vibrant blooms and lush foliage. In hotter climates, however, some afternoon shade may help prevent leaf burn and prolong flowering periods. When planting, aim for spots that maximize sunlight exposure, like the central areas of ponds. If grown indoors or in greenhouses, ensure ample light using grow lights, mimicking natural sunlight conditions. Adequate light is crucial to sustaining the plant's health and vigor throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"When caring for Nymphaea nouchali, regular pruning is needed to maintain plant health. Remove yellowing or dead leaves by cutting close to their base. This encourages new growth and prevents decay that could affect water quality. In cooler climates, the plant may die back in winter; in this case, trim the foliage back and remove dead material. Doing so prevents rot and helps maintain a healthy balance in water gardens or ponds. Also, thinning out dense growth areas will improve water circulation and light penetration during the growing season."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Day Waterlily","description":"Nymphaea nouchali, often known by its synonym Nymphaea stellata, or by common names blue lotus, star lotus, red water lily, dwarf aquarium lily, blue water lily, blue star water lily or manel flower, is a water lily of genus Nymphaea. It is native to southern and eastern parts of Asia, and is the national flower of Bangladesh and Sri Lanka. In Sanskrit, it is utpala. This species is usually considered to include the blue Egyptian lotus","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Asia","Australia"],"other_name":["Day Waterlily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Nematodes"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Rhizome Division"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Nymphaea nouchali"],"soil":["Rich organic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16850,"attracts":"[,\"Bees\",\"Birds\"]","care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Poa arachnifera, commonly known as Texas bluegrass, prefers well-drained soil and does not require excessive watering. It is drought-tolerant and benefits from a regular but moderate watering schedule, particularly during establishment and dry spells. Generally, watering once a week is sufficient, increasing to twice a week during particularly hot and dry weather. Ensure the soil dries out between watering sessions to avoid waterlogging and root rot. Newly planted areas may need more frequent watering until the grass establishes thoroughly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Texas bluegrass thrives in full sunlight to partial shade. Ideally, it requires at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day to grow optimally. However, it can tolerate some shade and may still perform well in areas with dappled sunlight. When planting in a shaded location, ensure the shade is not too dense, as insufficient light can reduce vigor and growth rate. Balancing sun exposure is key to preventing the plant from becoming leggy or weak. Proper positioning will promote robust growth and vibrant color."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Poa arachnifera does not require regular pruning, but occasional mowing is necessary to maintain its appearance and health. It is best to water this plant during its active growing season, which is in the warmer months. Allow the soil to dry completely between waterings. In the winter, reduce watering significantly, as the plant is in a dormant phase and too much moisture can lead to fungal diseases. Watering once a month in the cooler months is usually sufficient. Always water at the base and avoid wetting the stem to prevent rot or mildew development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cephalocereus senilis thrives in bright, direct sunlight, simulating its natural desert habitat. Gradually acclimate the plant to full sunlight to prevent sunburn. In regions with very intense sun, especially during summer, some light shade during the hottest part of the day can help prevent damage to the plant’s outer skin. Consistent exposure to bright light encourages healthy growth and maintains its characteristic appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cephalocereus senilis is generally minimal since it grows slowly and naturally takes on a distinctive appearance with its long white hairs. However, you may occasionally need to remove any dead or dying parts of the plant to encourage healthy growth. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut off the dead sections cleanly. If the cactus develops too many offsets, they can be carefully pruned or separated to propagate new plants. Handle with care to avoid damaging the fibers that give this cactus its signature look."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"old man cactus","description":"Cephalocereus senilis (old man cactus) is a species of cactus native to Guanajuato and Hidalgo in eastern Mexico. Mulching can help retain moisture in the soil, especially over warmer months. Once established, it may tolerate occasional dry periods but thrives best with regular moisture. Adjust watering frequency based on seasonal rainfall and soil drainage conditions. Always check the topsoil for moisture before watering to prevent overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Symphyotrichum praealtum thrives best in full sun conditions, meaning it requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to perform optimally. While it can tolerate partial shade, particularly in hotter climates, full sun exposure ensures the most vigorous growth and abundant flowering. Placing the plant in a location with good sun exposure will support its natural blooming cycle, leading to a more impressive display of its daisy-like flowers. In areas with extremely hot or dry climates, a bit of afternoon shade can help protect the plant from stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Symphyotrichum praealtum involves cutting back the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This cleanup involves removing any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy, vigorous growth. Deadheading spent flowers during the blooming season can encourage prolonged blooming and prevent self-seeding if not desired. Additionally, cutting back the plant by about one-third in early summer can help maintain a compact shape and encourage bushier growth. This also helps prevent the plant from becoming leggy. Regular pruning helps improve air circulation and reduces the likelihood of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"willowleaf aster","description":"Symphyotrichum praealtum, known as willowleaf aster and willow aster is a species of flowering plant in the aster family, Asteraceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17447,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Globifomes graveolens, commonly known as a type of bracket fungus, does not require traditional watering like a houseplant since it primarily grows in natural settings on decaying wood. However, maintaining a moist environment is crucial if trying to cultivate or observe this fungus indoors for educational purposes. Ensure the substrate it grows on, such as a wood log, is kept moist but not waterlogged. A humidity of 60-80% can support its growth, mimicking the damp conditions it naturally thrives in. Utilize a spray bottle to mist around its habitat occasionally to maintain proper moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Globifomes graveolens, like most fungi, does not require direct sunlight to grow since it naturally develops in shaded and damp woodland environments. Recreating this environment for cultivation means providing indirect or dappled light, mimicking the natural forest canopy under which it typically thrives. Avoid exposing it to direct sunlight, as this can dry out the substrate quickly and hinder its growth. Instead, a location with indirect sunlight, such as a shaded corner or under other taller plants, will allow the fungus to replicate its natural habitat conditions effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a mushroom, Globifomes graveolens does not require pruning like plants do. Instead, focus should be on managing the substrate it grows on. If you're cultivating this fungus, ensure it has ample space and resources to spread. Remove any competing or obstructive organisms from its immediate environment to allow optimal growth. Regularly monitor and, if necessary, remove any diseased or overly decayed sections of the substrate to prevent rotting and ensure a healthy growth area. This management can help foster a conducive environment for the optimum growth of the fungus."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sweet knot","description":"Globifomes is a fungal genus in the family Polyporaceae. It is a monotypic genus, containing the single North American species Globifomes graveolens, commonly known as sweet knot. This fungus is found fruiting singly or in groups on trunks or logs of hardwood trees, primarily oaks. The fruit body consists of a mass of small overlapping hoof-shaped caps arising from a common core. It is initially dull yellow-brown with tan petal-shaped margins, aging to dark brown.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Sweet knot"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal infections"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Globifomes graveolens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

The plant's preference for ample sunlight helps in photosynthesis and overall development, leading to a richer flavor and aroma in the seeds. When planting in a garden, choose a spot with maximum sun exposure, and if growing indoors, place near a south-facing window or use supplemental grow lights to ensure adequate light levels."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of caraway plants should be focused on promoting healthy growth and removing dead or diseased foliage. Cut back the plant after it has flowered to encourage new growth and potentially a second flowering. Remove spent flower stems and any damaged leaves periodically to maintain its shape and health. Caraway does not require heavy pruning, but regular light pruning can enhance overall plant vigor and air circulation, reducing disease risk. Deadheading can also prevent unwanted self-seeding, helping manage plant spread in your garden."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Caraway","description":"Caraway, also known as meridian fennel and Persian cumin (Carum carvi), is a biennial plant in the family Apiaceae, native to western Asia, Europe, and North Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Caraway"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Carrot rust fly"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Carum carvi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17244,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphorbia characias prefers well-draining soil and should be watered sparingly. It is drought-tolerant and can withstand periods of low water, making it ideal for Mediterranean or dry gardens. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season, you can water once every two weeks, but reduce this frequency significantly in the fall and winter months. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it’s important to ensure good drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia characias thrives in full sunlight and should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. It can also tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, but too much shade can result in leggy growth and fewer flowers. Plant it in a location where it can enjoy morning sun with some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch in particularly hot areas. Ensure it is placed in an open area to allow good airflow, which will help prevent fungal issues."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Euphorbia characias in late spring or early summer, after it has finished flowering. Cut back the flowering stems down to the base to encourage new growth and maintain a tidy shape. Always wear gloves and protective clothing when pruning, as the milky sap can be irritating or toxic. Regularly removing spent flowers and damaged or congested growth helps keep the plant healthy. Avoid pruning new season stems, as this will remove next year’s flowers. Deadheading regularly throughout the blooming season can encourage longer blooming periods."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mediterranean spurge","description":"Euphorbia characias, the Mediterranean spurge or Albanian spurge, is a species of flowering plant in the Euphorbiaceae family typical of the Mediterranean vegetation. It is an upright, compact evergreen shrub growing to 1.2 m (3 ft 11 in) tall and wide.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish-yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean region"],"other_name":["Mediterranean spurge"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia characias"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17941,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Bauhinia divaricata, commonly known as the Butterfly Tree, requires a moderate watering routine. It's important to allow the topsoil to dry out between waterings to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water the plant thoroughly once a week or when the soil feels dry to the touch. During the dormant winter months, reduce the frequency of watering, ensuring that the plant does not remain in overly moist conditions. Always use well-draining soil to help manage moisture levels effectively."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bauhinia divaricata thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to promote healthy growth and flowering. When planted in areas with hot, intense sun, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from excessive heat and leaf scorch. However, too much shade may result in reduced flowering and slower growth. Ideally, position the plant in a location where it receives morning sun and some protection from the harsh afternoon rays, allowing it to develop optimally."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential for the healthy growth of Bauhinia divaricata. This should be done during its dormancy period in late winter or early spring before the new growth starts. Remove any dead or diseased branches, and cut back overgrown stems to maintain the desired shape. It's also essential to prune any crossing branches to improve air circulation within the plant. Pruning helps encourage a bushier growth habit and can enhance flower production during the blooming season. Using clean, sharp tools is crucial to prevent any damage or disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pom Pom Orchid Tree","description":"Bauhinia divaricata is a species of flowering shrub of the family Fabaceae. B. divaricata is the type species of the genus Bauhinia. One common name for this species is pom pom orchid tree. It is native to China, Jamaica, India and also grows in the southern half of Florida. It has white bi-lobed leaves that alternate.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South China","Southeast Asia"],"other_name":["Pom Pom Orchid Tree"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Bauhinia divaricata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16651,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mentzelia nuda, commonly known as the stickleaf or blazing star, thrives in dry conditions and requires minimal watering. It is drought-tolerant and can suffer from overwatering, so it's crucial to let the soil almost completely dry out between waterings. During its growing season, water sparingly, only when the soil feels dry to touch a few inches down. In winter, reduce watering significantly or stop altogether to prevent root rot, as the plant enters a dormant phase and needs little to no moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mentzelia nuda thrives best in full sunlight and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight a day. This hardy plant is well-suited to sunny gardens and will perform wonderfully in bright conditions, where it can develop its full array of striking yellow flowers. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and a reduction in blooming, so ensure it is planted in a location that is not shaded by taller plants or structures. Full sun will help maintain its robust growth and vibrant appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mentzelia nuda is not typically necessary, as its natural form is part of its aesthetic charm. However, occasional deadheading can encourage more blooms and maintain a tidy appearance. Remove spent flowers by cutting them off at the base of the bloom to prevent seed formation and promote further flowering. If the plant becomes leggy or overgrown, trim back excessive growth in early spring before new growth begins. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruners to reduce the risk of disease and infection."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Bractless Blazingstar","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["USA","Canada"],"other_name":["Bractless Blazingstar"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Mentzelia nuda"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17743,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ferocactus latispinus, commonly known as the devil’s tongue cactus, prefers a well-draining soil and should be watered thoroughly but infrequently. It’s important to allow the soil to dry completely between waterings, especially during its dormant period in the winter months. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to ensure the soil is dry to the touch before water is added. During the active growing season in spring and summer, slightly increase the frequency of watering to encourage growth, but still be cautious of excess moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This cactus thrives in bright light and can tolerate full sun. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day, particularly in the cooler months. During summer, if the sunlight is too intense, especially in very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent sunburn, which appears as brown or white patches on the skin. If grown indoors, placing it near a south or west-facing window will provide adequate light. Inadequate sunlight can lead to etiolated growth, where the cactus becomes elongated and pale."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Ferocactus latispinus requires minimal pruning, as it naturally maintains its spherical to cylindrical shape. Pruning is primarily needed to remove dead or damaged spines or if there is any sign of rot. The best time to prune is during the growing season, avoiding the dormant winter period. If pruning is necessary, use sterilized tools to prevent disease, and avoid cutting too close to the main body to minimize stress on the plant. Always handle the cactus carefully, as its spines can be sharp and cause injury."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Devil's Tongue Barrel Cactus","description":"Ferocactus latispinus is a species of barrel cactus native to Mexico. Originally described as Cactus latispinus in 1824 by English naturalist Adrian Hardy Haworth, it gained its current name in 1922 with the erection of the genus Ferocactus by American botanists Britton and Rose. The species name is derived from the Latin latus \"broad\", and spinus \"spine\". Ferocactus recurvus is a former name for the species.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Devil's Tongue Barrel Cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Scales"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Ferocactus latispinus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Overwatering can lead to root rot while underwatering can cause the leaves to wilt and drop."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least five to six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade is beneficial to protect it from intense heat and light, which can scorch the leaves. If grown indoors, place Tibouchina semidecandra near a south-facing window to ensure it receives ample light. Adjust its position accordingly if the plant shows signs of too much or too little sunlight, such as leaf browning or sparse flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tibouchina semidecandra helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. Ideally, prune after the plant has finished blooming in late fall or early spring. Remove any dead, damaged, or weak branches first. To encourage a fuller plant, trim back the tips of the branches by a few inches, but avoid excessive pruning, as it may reduce flowering. By keeping up with regular pruning, you can control the size of the plant and ensure more abundant floral displays in the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"princess flower","description":"Tibouchina semidecandra, the princess flower, glory bush, or lasiandra, is a sprawling, evergreen shrub or small ornamental tree native to Brazil and ranges from 10 to 15 feet (20 feet with proper training) in height. The dark green, velvety, four to six-inch-long leaves have several prominent longitudinal veins instead of the usual one, and are often edged in red. Large,...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Brazil"],"other_name":["princess flower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Tibouchina semidecandra"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17245,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Moraea polystachya, known as the peacock moraea, requires moderate watering. During its active growth period in late fall to spring, water the plant regularly to keep the soil slightly moist but not waterlogged. It is important to allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In its dormant summer period, reduce watering significantly and allow the soil to dry out completely. Over-watering during dormancy can lead to bulb rot and should be avoided to ensure healthy growth during the next cycle."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Moraea polystachya thrives in full sun conditions and should be placed in a location where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. This exposure is crucial for proper blooming and overall healthy growth. In areas with very hot climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent the plant from getting scorched. However, in less intense climates, full sun throughout the day is ideal. Insufficient sunlight can lead to legginess and poor flowering, so ensure it gets adequate light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Moraea polystachya generally involves removing spent flowers and any dead or yellowing foliage. This promotes a neat appearance and directs the plant's energy towards healthy growth and new blooms. Cut the flower stalks back to the base after flowering to encourage bulb rejuvenation. Since it is a bulbous plant, major pruning is not typically required. It's also beneficial to remove any leaves that show signs of disease or damage immediately to prevent infection from spreading."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Karoo Tulp","description":"Moraea polystachya is a species of plant in the family Iridaceae native to southern Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Karoo Tulp"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Moraea polystachya"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18030,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sedum hirsutum is a drought-tolerant succulent that requires minimal watering. Allow the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water the plant every two weeks ensuring excess water drains away to prevent root rot. In the dormant winter months, reduce watering to once a month or less. Always check the soil moisture by sticking your finger into the soil—if it feels dry, it's time to water. These plants prefer being under-watered rather than over-watered."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sedum hirsutum thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to maintain its compact growth form and vibrant foliage color. It is well-suited for outdoor rock gardens or container gardens in bright, sunny locations. If grown indoors, place it in a south or west-facing window where it can receive plenty of light. Insufficient sunlight may cause the plant to become leggy and lose its vibrant appearance. During the hottest part of the day, some light shade can prevent leaf scorch, but generally, more sun leads to healthier growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sedum hirsutum is generally simple and revolves around removing dead or damaged foliage. Prune in early spring to encourage healthy growth as the plant comes out of dormancy. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to trim away dead or discolored leaves or stems, cutting at an angle close to the healthy part of the plant. Also, remove any spent flowers after blooming to maintain a neat appearance. Pruning helps prevent pests and diseases while promoting a bushier and more aesthetically pleasing plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Sedum hirsutum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravely","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16452,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Halenia deflexa prefers moist but well-drained soil conditions. During its active growing season, make sure to water the plant regularly to maintain consistent moisture in the soil. However, avoid waterlogging as it can lead to root rot. During the dormant period, reduce watering but do not let the soil dry out completely. Mulching can help retain moisture in the soil. Adjust the watering frequency based on the plant's specific environment, such as temperature and humidity."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Halenia deflexa thrives in partial shade conditions. It can tolerate some direct sunlight, but prolonged exposure to intense sun may cause leaf scorch. Ideally, it should receive morning sunlight followed by afternoon shade. If grown indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window. Avoid placing it in complete shade or low-light conditions as this can hinder growth and flowering. Adjust its location based on seasonal changes to ensure it receives adequate but not excessive light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Halenia deflexa is generally minimal, as it does not require heavy maintenance. Remove any dead or damaged leaves or stems to promote healthy growth and prevent disease. Pruning can be done during the growing season or after blooming to tidy up the plant’s appearance. Regular deadheading of spent flowers may encourage a longer blooming period. Water this plant regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Ensure that the soil or potting mix has good drainage to prevent root rot. Watering is crucial during dry spells, but reduce frequency in fall and winter when the plant is dormant. An effective method is to check the top inch of soil; if it feels dry to the touch, it is time to water. Ideally, Lilium bulbiferum should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to promote optimal growth and flowering. Planting in a location with good air circulation is also beneficial in preventing diseases. While it's a sun-loving plant, partial shade conditions can be tolerated but may lead to reduced flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lilium bulbiferum involves removing spent flowers to encourage longer blooming, which also prevents the plant from directing energy into seed production. Once the foliage has naturally yellowed and died back, it can safely be cut down to the base. It's essential to use clean pruning tools to avoid transferring any diseases. Regularly removing dead or damaged parts can also help improve airflow and prevent fungal problems."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fire lily","description":"Lilium bulbiferum, common names orange lily, fire lily and tiger lily, is a herbaceous European lily with underground bulbs, belonging to the Liliaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["fire lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf miners","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Division"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Lilium bulbiferum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16851,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Podranea ricasoliana, commonly known as the pink trumpet vine, enjoys consistent moisture in well-draining soil. Water the plant deeply once a week, allowing the soil to dry somewhat between waterings. During hot, dry weather, increase the frequency to prevent wilting. However, be cautious not to overwater, as the plant is susceptible to root rot. In winter, reduce watering as the plant enters a semi-dormant state, especially if grown in cooler climates. Always ensure the plant has good drainage to avoid waterlogged soil, which can lead to root disease."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Podranea ricasoliana prefers full sun to part shade, thriving in bright conditions. Ideally, give the plant at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal flowering and lush growth. In very hot or dry climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf burn and dehydration. The pink trumpet vine can tolerate light shade, but flowering may be reduced. If growing indoors or in a container, place the plant in a bright, sunny spot, ensuring it gets ample light to mimic outdoor conditions. Avoid deep shade as it may lead to sparse growth and fewer blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Podranea ricasoliana is essential to control its vigorous growth and to maintain a desired shape and size. The best time to prune is in early spring, just before the new growth begins. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased stems back to healthy wood. Trim back overgrown or wayward branches to promote bushier growth. Regularly remove any suckers that emerge at the base. For established plants, prune older woody stems to encourage new growth. This vine can be cut back hard without harm, making it manageable in most garden settings."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pink Trumpet Vine","description":"Podranea ricasoliana, called the pink trumpet vine, is a species of flowering plant in the genus Podranea, native to South Africa, Malawi, Mozambique and Zambia. Remove any crossing branches to prevent damage and improve air circulation within the plant. Avoid heavy pruning as it may reduce next season's blooms. After pruning, clean and disinfect tools to prevent the spread of disease. Pruning also helps control the plant's size and enhances the overall health and structure of the shrub."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese snowball","description":"Viburnum plicatum (Japanese: yabudemari, oodemari), common name Japanese snowball, is a species of flowering plant in the family Adoxaceae (formerly Caprifoliaceae), native to mainland China, Korea, Japan, and Taiwan.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Japan","China","Taiwan"],"other_name":["Japanese snowball"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Scale insects","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Viburnum plicatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, too much shade can lead to fewer flowers and leggy growth. Ensure the planting site balances adequate sunlight with some protection from the harshest afternoon rays. If grown in partial shade, ensure it's still a bright location to meet the plant's light needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Symphyotrichum shortii mainly involves removing dead or damaged stems which should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Regular deadheading during blooming season is beneficial as it encourages the plant to produce more flowers and extends its blooming period.

After the plant has completed its flowering cycle in late fall, you can cut back the stems to a few inches above the ground. This not only helps in managing plant size but also prevents the plant from self-seeding excessively. In general, watering once every 7-10 days should suffice during its growing season, particularly in the warmer months. During the winter or dormant period, reduce watering frequency as the plant's water needs are drastically lower. Always adjust based on your local climate and the specific environmental conditions where the plant is located."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crotalaria retusa thrives in full sun locations where it can receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. This exposure to light is essential as it supports flowering and overall growth. A sunny location also helps to prevent leggy growth, ensuring a more compact and robust plant. If growing indoors or in a shaded area, consider supplementing with a grow light to provide sufficient illumination. While it can tolerate some light shade, heavy shading will result in reduced flowering and weaker plants, so aim for an environment with ample sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crotalaria retusa involves removing dead or damaged branches to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any diseased or weak stems, cutting back to a healthy section or to the plant's base. This plant generally does not require heavy pruning, but regular maintenance can help control its size and improve air circulation. Be sure to use clean, sharp pruning shears to make precise cuts and reduce the risk of infection."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rattleweed","description":"Crotalaria retusa is a species of flowering plant in the legume family known by various common names including devil-bean, rattleweed, shack shack, and wedge-leaf rattlepod. It has been introduced as a crop plant in many tropical areas and has escaped from cultivation to become a troublesome weed; it is listed as a noxious weed...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australasia","Tropical Asia"],"other_name":["Rattleweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Crotalaria retusa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17644,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lilium michauxii, commonly known as the Carolina lily, prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. It is important to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during its growing and blooming seasons. Water thoroughly whenever the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch, but avoid waterlogging as it can lead to root rot. Use a mulch layer to retain soil moisture and to prevent evaporative loss. During its dormant season, reduce watering frequency significantly, allowing the plant to experience a drier period relative to its growing season needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carolina lilies thrive in partial to full sunlight conditions. They require at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. In hotter climates, providing some shade during the peak midday hours can prevent leaf scorching. A location with morning sun and afternoon shade typically works best as it ensures enough light while protecting the plant from intense heat stress. Ensure that the planting site is not overly shaded, as this will reduce flowering and result in leggy plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lilium michauxii is minimal and primarily involves cleaning up dead or dying leaves and spent flower stalks to maintain plant health and aesthetics. Remove withered blooms promptly to prevent seed pod formation and conserve the plant's energy. After the flowering season, allow the leaves to die back naturally as they are vital for storing energy in the bulb for the next growth cycle. Trim away dead foliage at the base once it's completely yellowed and abscised naturally to reduce the risk of disease and pests."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Carolina lily","description":"Lilium michauxii, commonly known as the Carolina lily, can be found in the Southeastern United States from southern Virginia in the north to the Florida Panhandle in the south to eastern Texas in the west. It is most common in July and August but can be found blooming as late as October. It was named for the French botanist André Michaux, who traveled and did extensive research throughout the Southeast.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Carolina lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Virus","Thrips"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lilium michauxii"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Pruning cuts should always be clean and made just above a leaf node or bud to encourage healthy new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Two-wing Silverbell","description":"Halesia diptera, the two-wing silverbell or two-winged snowdrop tree, is a species in the family Styracaceae, native to the southeastern United States from South Carolina and Florida west to eastern Texas. However, if the cactus is kept indoors, place it near the brightest window available, preferably south-facing, where it can receive ample light. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17149,"attracts":["Bees","Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Viburnum recognitum, commonly known as Northern Arrowwood, thrives in consistently moist soil, although it can tolerate occasional dry spells. To maintain optimal health, water this plant thoroughly during its growing season, particularly in periods of extended dry weather. Ensure the soil is well-drained to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During the fall and winter months, reduce watering, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Mulching can aid in moisture retention and temperature regulation, benefiting the plant’s root system throughout the year."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viburnum recognitum prefers partial to full sun exposure to thrive, performing optimally with at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from excessive transpiration and heat stress. When planted in too much shade, the flowering and fruiting of the plant may be reduced, and the growth can become leggy. Ensuring the plant receives adequate sunlight will promote healthy foliage, abundant blooms, and a well-rounded shape."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viburnum recognitum should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins, as it flowers on old wood. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain plant health. To control size and encourage a more compact growth habit, selectively prune branches back to their base. If shaping is desired, trim to improve structure and airflow within the plant. Regularly remove suckers that appear at the base to maintain the desired form and prevent the shrub from becoming too dense and unruly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"northern arrowwood","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["northern arrowwood"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Viburnum recognitum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16552,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Jatropha cinerea is a drought-tolerant shrub, and excessive watering can harm it. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, water the plant moderately, allowing the top inches of soil to dry out between waterings. In fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, especially in cooler climates where dormancy occurs. Over-watering is a common mistake with Jatropha, so ensure the soil is well-draining, and pots have adequate drainage holes if grown in containers."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Jatropha cinerea thrives in full sun and will perform best when provided with direct sunlight for at least 6 to 8 hours a day. Although it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to reduced flowering and a leggier appearance. Ensure the plant is positioned in a location that receives ample sunshine throughout the day, especially if planted outdoors in gardens. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window where it can receive bright, consistent light. Adequate sunlight helps maintain healthy growth and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Jatropha cinerea should be done to maintain the desired shape and promote healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches, which improves air circulation and encourages new growth. Cut back long or leggy stems to maintain compactness, and always prune just above a leaf node or bud. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant, and remember to sterilize your tools to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Ashy Jatropha","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Ashy Jatropha"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Jatropha cinerea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17449,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Athyrium angustum, commonly known as Northern Lady Fern, thrives in consistently moist soil. During the growing season, it's important to water it regularly to maintain evenly moist conditions, but be cautious to avoid waterlogging, as this can lead to root rot. Reducing watering slightly in the winter months is recommended when the plant's growth slows down. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain an ideal growing environment. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Athyrium angustum prefers partial to full shade environments, making it ideal for shaded garden areas or woodland settings. Direct sunlight can scorch the fronds, so it's best to protect it from harsh afternoon sun. When planting this fern indoors, place it in a location that receives filtered or indirect light to mimic its natural habitat conditions. While it can tolerate deeper shade, optimal frond development occurs with some indirect light access. Adjust placement based on light availability and season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Athyrium angustum involves removing dead or damaged fronds to encourage healthy growth and maintain its appearance. This can be done at any time of the year, but the best practice is to trim dead fronds in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Be sure to use sterilized pruning tools to prevent the spread of diseases. Avoid cutting into the crown of the plant as this can cause damage. Regular pruning helps to promote airflow and reduce potential pest issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"northern lady fern","description":"Athyrium angustum is known as the northern lady fern, native to northeastern North America. It was long included in the superspecies Athyrium filix-femina, but is now largely recognized as a distinct species.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["northern lady fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Athyrium angustum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17247,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Polygala myrtifolia, commonly known as myrtle-leaf milkwort, prefers regular watering, particularly during dry spells. While it can tolerate some drought once established, it thrives with moderate moisture. Ensure the soil dries out slightly between watering to prevent root rot. In the growing season, water once or twice a week, adjusting based on rainfall and temperature. Reduce watering during the winter when the plant is dormant, taking care not to let the soil remain waterlogged. Over-watering is a common issue, so it's crucial to provide well-drained soil to keep this plant healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polygala myrtifolia flourishes in full sun but can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure prolific blooming and healthy growth. In very hot and dry regions, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorching and stress. Partial sun conditions may lead to fewer flowers and a leggier plant structure. Positioning it in a location with morning sun and some afternoon shade works well in regions with intense sunlight. Ensure its sunlight needs are met for robust health and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Polygala myrtifolia helps maintain its shape and encourages dense growth, resulting in more blooms. It's best to prune after the main flowering period has ended. Use sharp shears to remove any dead or crossing branches, and cut back excess growth to maintain the desired shape. Avoid heavy pruning into old wood, as this may not produce new growth. Light pruning can also be done throughout the growing season to deadhead spent flowers and promote further blooming. Regular pruning not only keeps the plant neat but also enhances flowering intensity."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sweet Pea Shrub","description":"Polygala myrtifolia L., the myrtle-leaf milkwort, is an evergreen 2-4m tall South African shrub or small tree found along the southern and south-eastern coasts, from near Clanwilliam in the Western Cape to KwaZulu-Natal. It is a fast-growing pioneer plant, a typical fynbos component, and may be found on dunes, rocky places, along forest margins, beside streams, and in open grassland. It belongs to the milkwort family of Polygalaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Sweet Pea Shrub"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Polygala myrtifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Aim to water the plant only when the soil feels dry about an inch below the surface. During prolonged dry periods, occasional watering can support its growth, but in most natural settings, rainfall generally suffices for its water needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crotalaria sagittalis thrives in full sun to partial shade. It is best to provide this plant with at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to optimize its growth and flowering potential. While it can tolerate some light shade, insufficient sunlight can lead to reduced flowering and a straggly appearance. In regions with extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent excessive heat stress, though morning sun should be prioritized."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crotalaria sagittalis isn't generally necessary, as it is a naturally low-growing and bushy plant. However, you can remove dead or diseased branches to maintain plant health and appearance. If the plant starts to become leggy or too large for its space, pruning can encourage bushier growth. This should be done in the growing season by trimming back the tops of the stems. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"arrowhead rattlebox","description":"Crotalaria sagittalis, known as arrowhead rattlebox or just rattlebox, is an annual wildflower native to the United States, Midwestern and Eastern states....","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["arrowhead rattlebox"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Crotalaria sagittalis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16947,"attracts":["Bees","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sairocarpus vexillocalyculatus, like many flowering plants, prefers a well-draining soil and a consistent watering routine to thrive. It's essential to water this plant thoroughly, allowing excess water to drain away to prevent root rot. During the growing season, keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. It's generally best to water when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. In the cooler months or when the plant is not actively growing, reduce watering and let the soil dry out more between waterings to avoid overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sairocarpus vexillocalyculatus thrives in environments where it can receive plenty of bright, indirect sunlight. Ideally, it should be placed in a location where it can receive filtered sunlight for most of the day, such as near a bright window if grown indoors, or in partial shade if outdoors. Direct sunlight for prolonged periods may cause leaf burn and stress the plant, so it's crucial to avoid placing it in harsh, direct sunlight. During the winter months, supplementing with grow lights may be beneficial to ensure it receives adequate light for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sairocarpus vexillocalyculatus should be done primarily to promote healthy growth and manage size. Remove any dead or damaged stems and leaves as they appear. During the growing season, you can prune back overgrown parts to encourage a bushier appearance and promote new growth. Take care to use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts. Pruning can also be used to remove spent flowers, which encourages the plant to produce more blooms, thus maintaining its vibrant and attractive appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"wiry snapdragon","description":"Antirrhinum vexillo-calyculatum (syn. Sairocarpus vexillocalyculatus (Kellogg) D.A. Sutton) is a species of New World snapdragon found only in California and occasionally Oregon. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18032,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Iris japonica, or the Japanese iris, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. It's important to avoid letting the soil dry out completely, as this can negatively affect flowering and growth. However, it should not be waterlogged as well, which can cause root rot. Water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil is evenly moist but not soggy. During the winter months, you can reduce watering as the plant's growth slows down. Always ensure the pot or bed has good drainage to prevent water buildup."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Iris japonica thrives best in partial to full shade, making it an excellent choice for gardens with limited direct sunlight. While it can tolerate some sun, especially in cooler regions, exposure to excessive direct sunlight in hot climates can lead to leaf burns or excessive soil drying. Ideally, place it in a location that receives dappled sunlight or morning sun with afternoon shade. This will ensure healthy growth and optimal blooming. The plant's preference for shade makes it a versatile option for filling lower-light garden areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Iris japonica is typically done to remove spent flower stalks and any brown or damaged leaves, which helps keep the plant tidy and may encourage further blooming. After the flowering period, cut the flower stems down to the base. Leaves can be tidied up by removing any dead or yellowing foliage. In late autumn or early spring, you can cut back the leaves to a few inches above the ground to encourage fresh growth. Regularly pruning and removing debris will also help prevent disease and pest issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fringed Iris","description":"Iris japonica (also known as 'fringed iris', 'shaga' or 'butterfly flower') is a native of China and Japan. During the growing season, spring and summer, water the plant moderately, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. This generally means watering every 2-3 weeks depending on the environmental conditions. In fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, as the plant enters its dormant period. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is crucial that the soil dries completely before re-watering. Ensuring the pot has proper drainage holes is also important to prevent excess water retention."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mammillaria haageana thrives in bright, indirect light. It can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in the morning, but prolonged exposure to harsh afternoon sun can cause the plant to sunburn. Ideally, place this cactus near a south-facing window where it can receive several hours of bright, but filtered, sunlight each day. If kept outdoors during warmer months, slowly acclimate it to increased sunlight to prevent stress or damage. In winter, ensure it still receives sufficient light, potentially supplementing with artificial grow lights if natural light is limited."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mammillaria haageana is generally not necessary, as cacti grow slowly and maintain their shape. However, removing dead or damaged stems is beneficial to promote overall plant health and manage space if the cactus becomes crowded. If pruning is desired, use sterile, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent damage to the plant and the introduction of disease. Prune during the plant's dormant period, typically in the winter, and take care not to disturb healthy tissues or expose too much of the plant to potential pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Mammillaria haageana is a species of cacti in the subtribe Cactinae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16352,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eragrostis superba, or Weeping Love Grass, is a drought-tolerant species, making it relatively low-maintenance with regards to watering. During establishment, it requires regular watering to promote root development. Once established, it is highly drought-resistant and requires minimal watering. Over-watering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. In extremely dry conditions, occasional deep watering can help maintain its lush appearance, but generally, natural rainfall will suffice for mature plants. It’s best to allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions, reflecting its adaptation to arid environments."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eragrostis superba thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to flourish. This sunlight exposure helps the plant maintain its vibrant color and overall health. Though it can tolerate partial shade, it may not perform as well or produce as many flowers. Full sunlight exposure supports its natural growth cycle, enhances its drought resistance, and helps in developing a robust and deep root system. Its adaptability to hot and sunny conditions makes it ideal for areas with consistent sunlight, ensuring optimal growth and vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Eragrostis superba is usually minimal. Regular removal of dead or damaged blades promotes healthier growth and maintains its appearance. At the end of the growing season, in regions with frosts or harsh winters, it's recommended to cut back the dry foliage to a few inches above the ground. This clean-up method not only makes way for new growth in spring but also reduces shelter for pests over winter. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season, as this grass thrives when allowed to grow naturally without significant intervention."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Wilman lovegrass","description":"Eragrostis superba is a species of perennial tufted grass in the Poaceae family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16163,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cassytha filiformis, commonly known as 'love vine', typically thrives in well-drained soils where it does not require frequent watering. As a parasitic plant, it generally absorbs moisture through its host, so if cultivated without a host, water it sparingly to mimic its natural environment. Overwatering can lead to root rot, especially in a container setting. Ensure that the medium is allowed to dry out somewhat between waterings to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cassytha filiformis requires ample sunlight to thrive, preferring full sun to partial shade conditions. In its natural habitat, it often grows in open, sunny areas where it can access direct sunlight for several hours a day. If grown in partial shade, it might exhibit slower growth. Ensure that its surrounding environment does not become too shaded by other vegetation, as adequate light is essential for its parasitic lifestyle and successful parasitization of host plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cassytha filiformis involves careful management of its growth, as this fast-growing plant can quickly overtake its host or surrounding plants. Trim vines as needed using clean, sharp scissors to control its spread and prevent excessive weight or nutrient competition with its host plant. Regular pruning helps maintain plant health and vigor, and should ideally be performed during active growth periods when the plant is most robust."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"laurel dodder","description":"Cassytha filiformis, common name love-vine, is a species of obligate parasitic vine in the family Lauraceae. The species has a pantropical distribution encompassing the Americas, Indomalaya, Australasia, Polynesia and East Africa In the Caribbean region, it is one of several plants known as \"Love vine\" because it has a reputation as an aphrodisiac.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Gray\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["Asia","Australia","Africa","Americas"],"other_name":["laurel dodder"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Cassytha filiformis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16753,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Parthenium confertum, like many other Parthenium species, is a drought-tolerant plant that doesn't require frequent watering. It's important to ensure that the soil is dry before watering again to prevent overwatering, which could lead to root rot. In general, provide water once every two weeks, adjusting based on local climate conditions. During prolonged dry spells or extreme heat, you might need to water more frequently, but always ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogged soil. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Parthenium confertum thrives in full sunlight but is tolerant of partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. In too much shade, the plant might become leggy and produce fewer blooms. Ensure it's planted in a location where it will not be shaded by larger plants or structures for most of the day. In extremely hot climates, a bit of afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense midday sun and heat stress. Consistent sunlight exposure will help maintain its robust growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Parthenium confertum is not always necessary unless you're managing its growth or preventing it from spreading aggressively. If pruning is needed, do so in the early spring before new growth starts. Use sharp, clean tools to cut back overgrown or damaged stems to promote healthier growth. Regularly remove any dead or diseased foliage to maintain plant health. Caution is advised as this plant might cause allergic reactions due to its pollen, so wearing gloves and protective clothing when pruning is recommended."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Gray's feverfew","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Gray's feverfew"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Parthenium confertum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
